title: Hermann Hesse is born in Calw, the son of the Pietist missionary couple Johannes and Maria Hesse (née Gundert) 1881 The Hesse family moves to Basel 1886 The Hesses return to Calw
Hesse attends the Latin School in Göppingen under Rector Bauer
Hesse passes the state examination and becomes a seminarian in Maulbronn

note: becomes a pupil at the high school in Cannstatt (from November
title: Hesse absconds from Maulbronn (after seven months); spends time with Pastor Christoph Blumhardt in Bad Boll; declares his intention to commit suicide; incarceration in the insane asylum at Stetten
Apprenticeship as a bookseller in Esslingen (for three days); time with his parents in Calw
Trainee at Perrot’s clockmaking workshop in Calw (for 14 months); Hesse considers emigrating to Brazil
Apprenticeship as a bookseller in Tübingen (at Heckenhauer’s bookshop
Hesse’s first poems are published in Das deutsche Dichterheim

note: Hesse’s Romantische Lieder appear (published by the vanity publisher E. Pierson in Dresden

title: The prose volume Eine Stunde hinter Mitternacht is published by Eugen Diederichs; Hesse moves to Basel; sales assistant in Reich’s bookshop
Begins contributing regular articles to the newspaper the Allgemeine Schweizer Zeitung

note: until spring 1903); Hermann Lauscher is published by R. Reich
title: First trip to Italy (from March to May); bookseller at the Wattenwyl antiquarian bookshop

note: Fischer publishing house; Peter Camenzind appears as a preprint in the Fischer in-house magazine Die neue Rundschau
title: Second Italian journey in the company of the Basel photographer Maria Bernoulli; invitation to become an author for the S

note: written 1903–1904); Hesse co-founds the anti-Wilhelmine magazine März (remaining its co-publisher until 1912) 1909 Hesse’s second son, Heiner, is born
title: Peter Camenzind becomes a best-seller; Hesse marries Maria Bernoulli and becomes a full-time writer; Hesse and Maria move into a house at Gaienhofen on Lake Constance 1905 Birth of Hesse’s first son, Bruno 1906 Publication of Unterm Rad
Gertrud is published by the Verlag Albert Langen in Munich
Hesse’s third son, Martin, is born; Hesse travels to “far India
Hesse moves permanently to Switzerland; takes up residence in the Welti house in Bern 1913 Publication of Aus Indien
Outbreak of the First World War; volunteers for war ser vice, rejected as unfit for active duty; publication of Roßhalde

note: donation ser vice to POW camps; Knulp published
title: Assigned to war work at the German embassy in Bern; active in the prisoners of war welfare ser vice (1919); publishes the newspaper Sonntagsbote für Kriegsgefangene (1916); instigates a book

note: Lang; undergoes first course of psychoanalysis
title: Death of Hesse’s father, Johannes; Maria Bernoulli shows the first signs of serious neurological disease; Hesse suffers a ner vous breakdown and spends time at the Sonnmatt sanatorium near Lucerne; start of Hesse’s friendship with the psychoanalyst J
Hesse publishes an antiwar article under the pseudonym Emil Sinclair

note: G. Jung in Küsnacht near Zu rich 1922 Hesse completes Siddhartha
title: Hesse writes the first part of the novel Siddhartha; suffers writer’s block and severe depression; undergoes a course of psychoanalysis with C

note: a practice he maintains until 1952
title: Divorce from Maria Bernoulli, who will thereafter spend many years in psychiatric institutions; takes the first of his rest cures at a spa in Baden near Zurich
Hesse readopts Swiss nationality; second marriage, to Ruth Wenger 1925 Publication of Kurgast

note: which he leaves in 1931
title: Hesse is made a member of the Prussian Academy of Arts

note: officially as Hesse’s secretary) 1928 The Krise cycle of poems is published
title: Hesse divorces Ruth Wenger; publication of the Nürnberger Reise and Der Steppenwolf; the first biography of Hermann Hesse, by Hugo Ball, appears on the occasion of his fiftieth birthday; death of Hugo Ball; Ninon Dolbin moves into Casa Camuzzi
Eine Bibliothek der Weltliteratur appears in the Reclam Universal Library series 1930 Publication of Narziß und Goldmund

note: C. Bodmer for Hesse and placed at his sole disposal for his lifetime); Hesse begins work on Das Glasperlenspiel 1932 Publication of Die Morgenlandfahrt
title: Marriage to Ninon Dolbin and shared occupancy of the newly constructed Casa Rossa in Montagnola (built by the benefactor H
Das Glasperlenspiel is published by Fretz & Wasmuth in Zu rich (Nazi authorities refuse Peter Suhrkamp the rights to publish the novel in Germany

note: and of the Nobel Prize for Liter ature; first German edition of Das Glasperlenspiel
title: Award to Hesse of the Goethe Prize of the City of Frankfurt am Main
Hesse becomes a leading author of the new Suhrkamp Verlag publishing house
Death of Peter Suhrkamp; Hesse’s reader Siegfried Unseld becomes the new head of Suhrkamp and remains in this post until his death in
